newsitem.title: USA: US FTC fines Mahle GmbH,Metal Leve $5 mln.
newsitem.headline: US FTC fines Mahle GmbH,Metal Leve $5 mln.

text.p: The Federal Trade Commission said Thursday that Germany's Mahle GmbH and Brazil's Metal Leve S.A. have agreed to pay a record fine of over $5 million over Mahle's purchase of a controlling stake in Leve.
The two companies were fined for failing to give federal antitrust enforcers advance notice of the acquisition.

The FTC said Metal Leve has also agreed to quickly sell off its U.S. piston business, including two plants in South Carolina and a development center in Michigan, to prevent a monopoly in pistons used primarily in heavy duty diesel engines.

"Violation of the reporting requirements of the antitrust laws is a very serious matter," William Baer, Director of the FTC's Bureau of Competition, said. "The reporting requirements serve as a critical early warning system to alert antitrust enforcers to potentially anticompetitive mergers."
The FTC said that the $5 million-plus penalty payment by Mahle and Metal Leve is a record civil fine for this type of violation.
Baer said that Mahle's purchase of a 50.1 percent stake in Metal Leve would have raised piston prices by as much as $25 million a year if the FTC had not acted.

"The divestiture we are requiring here will prevent a monopoly from forming and should save diesel engine manufacturers and, ultimately their consumers, millions of dollars," Baer said in a statement.

Both Mahle GMBH and Metal Leve S.A. manufacture diesel engine parts, including pistons, through U.S. subsidiaries -- Mahle Inc, of Morristwon, Tenn. and Metal Leve Inc of Ann Arbor, Mich., respectively, the FTC said.

The FTC said in a statement its attorneys would allege in court that Mahle acquired 50.1 percent of Metal Leve for about $40 million on or before June 26 last year without notifying the FTC or the Justice Department despite knowing the deal posed "serious anti-trust problems"
The consent agreement does not admit to a violation of law but binds the companies involved not to break the law in future.
Once the settlement becomes final the divestiture would have to be completed within 10 days.
"If that is not accomplished, then the FTC may appoint a trustee to divest the business," the FTC announced.
